elements.content: The increasing interest in coordination polymers, also called metal–organic frameworks, arises from their applications in separation, storage, and catalysis, for example. The design and preparation of these types of infinite architectures displaying translational symmetry may be based on the molecular tectonics approach, which considers both the organic moiety and the metallic center or complex as complementary tectons. Among many types of organic tectons, those based on macrocycles such as azacrown ethers, porphyrins, cucurbit[n]urils, and calix[4]arenes are interesting backbones because they are preorganized entities with, in same cases, restricted conformational space. Within the calix[4]arene family, tetrathiacalix[4]arenes (TCAs), for which all four CH2 groups connecting the aromatic moieties are substituted by S atoms, are particularly interesting for the design of organic tectons because they offer four additional thioether junctions that may take part in the coordination of metal centers. Using TCA derivatives in an 1,3-alternate (1,3-A) conformation bearing peripheral coordinating sites such as nitrile, carboxylate, or benzonitrile groups and propoxy groups, a variety of 1-, 2-, and 3D coordination networks have been obtained using the Ag+ cation as a connector. Tetramercaptotetrathiacalix[4]arene (1; Scheme ) is an analogue of TCA in which the four OH moieties are replaced by four SH groups. The latter offers eight S atoms, which may be involved in binding of the metal cations. Few examples of the functionalization of the lower rim of 1 have been described. The coordination propensity of 1 has been studied, and only a few discrete complexes have been reported for IrII and RhII, MoII, NiII and WII, and HgII. A specific HgII extracting agent based on an analogue of 1 bearing only two SH groups has also been reported.

elements.content: In this contribution, we report on the design, synthesis, and structural characterization of three new organic tectons 2–4 (Scheme ) and their combinations with HgCl2, leading to mercury coordination networks in the crystalline phase.

elements.content: Tectons 2–4, based on the parent compound 1 locked in the 1,3-A conformation (Scheme , right) bearing four monodentate pyridyl group as coordinating sites, are positional isomers and differ by the position of the N atom on the pyridyl moiety. Whereas 2 and 3, owing to the distance between the N and S atoms, should behave as tetrakis-monodentate units, 4, offering four NCCH2S moieties, can behave as a chelating ligand.

The starting material for the preparation of tectons 2–4 was compound 1. As for the TCA pyridyl-appended analogues, compounds 2–4 have been obtained at 25 °C in 53, 41, and 51% yield, respectively, upon condensation between the parent compound 1 and X-(chloromethyl)pyridine (X = 4 for 2, 3 for 3, and 2 for 4) in dry acetone in the presence of Cs2CO3. In all cases, only the 1,3-A conformation was isolated from the reaction mixture (see the , SI). Structures of 2–4 have been studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD) on single crystals (see the crystallographic table in the ). Crystals were obtained upon the slow diffusion (or evaporation) of CH3CN (or MeOH) into a CHCl3 solution of tectons 2–4 (see the ). As expected, the 1,3-A conformation was established for all three compounds (Figure S1, ). Whereas crystals of 4 contain CHCl3 molecules, 2 and 3 crystallize in the absence of solvent. For all three cases, the metrics for the macrocyclic part are close to those observed for the parent compound 1. Among the three structures, only for 2, two out the four tert-butyl groups are found to be disordered. Whereas for 2 and 3 the pyridyl groups are oriented almost perpendicularly to the main plane formed by the four S atoms connecting the aromatic rings (tilt angle between 75.9 and 83.7°), for 4 the tilt angle is considerably smaller (40.7°).

elements.content: For the formation of coordination networks, HgCl2 was chosen as the neutral metallic partner. The latter was shown to act as a neutral deformed tetrahedral node offering two free coordination sites in a V-type disposition, although examples with an extended coordination sphere have been also reported. Combinations of 2–4 with HgCl2 have been explored by the slow evaporation at 25 °C of a CHCl3 solution containing the organic part into a CH3OH solution of HgCl2 (see the ). In all cases, crystals suitable for XRD have been obtained reproducibly (see the ). For 2-HgCl2 and 3-HgCl2, the purity of the crystalline material was established by powder XRD (PXRD) on microcrystalline powders, which revealed a good match between the observed and simulated patterns (see the ). For 4-HgCl2, owing to decomposition of the microcrystalline powder, probably because of the loss of CHCl3 solvent molecules, no good-quality PXRD pattern could be obtained. In all three cases, the structural investigation revealed the formation of neutral mercury coordination networks 2-HgCl2, 3-HgCl2, and 4-HgCl2 discussed below.

elements.content: In the case of 2-HgCl2, the crystal [triclinic, P1̅, Hg2Cl4(C64H68N4S8)·(CHCl3)2] is composed of tecton 2 and Hg2+ cation, Cl– anion, and CHCl3 solvent molecules. The tecton/Hg2+ ratio is 1:2. Each Hg2+, surrounded by a N2Cl2 set [d Hg–N and d Hg–Cl in the 2.398(5)–2.508(5) and 2.3377(16)–2.3632(14) Å ranges, respectively] in a deformed tetrahedral coordination geometry [N–Hg–N, Cl–Hg–N, and Cl–Hg–Cl angles in the 82.04(16)–85.24(16)°, 90.91(12)–106.36(12)°, and 150.18(6)–159.81(6)° ranges, respectively], is linked to two consecutive tectons 2 through Hg–N bonds. Tecton 2 binds four Hg2+ cations through its four Npy atoms occupying the apexes of a deformed tetrahedron (Figure ).

elements.content: For a combination of the tecton 3 and HgCl2, the crystal [triclinic, P1̅, Hg4Cl8(C64H68N4S8)2] is exclusively composed of 3, Hg2+, and Cl–. The 3/Hg2+ ratio is 1:2. Each tecton 3 binds four Hg2+, and each cation bridges two consecutive tectons 3 (Figure ). Hg2+, acting again as a V-shaped connector as in the case of 2-HgCl2, is surrounded by a N2Cl2 set of atoms [d Hg–N and d Hg–Cl in the 2.365(8)–2.41(9) and 2.358(4)–2.393(4) Å ranges, respectively] and adopts a distorted T d coordination geometry [N–Hg–N, Cl–Hg–N, and Cl–Hg–Cl angles in the 91.0(4)–100.5(4)°, 96.2(3)–105(2)°, and 140.7(2)–150.19(15)° ranges, respectively]. The connectivity pattern leads to the formation of a 2D architecture, resulting from the bridging of consecutive tectons 3 by HgCl2 units through pyridyl–Hg bonds. As in the case of 2-HgCl2, the S atoms do not participate in the binding of the Hg2+ cation. The packing of consecutive sheets takes place along the b axis.

elements.content: Finally, in the case of 4-HgCl2, the crystal [monoclinic, C2/c, (Hg4Cl8)0.5(C64H68N4S8)0.5·(CHCl3)] is composed of 4 and Hg2+, Cl–, and CHCl3 solvent molecules. The tecton/Hg2+ ratio is 1:4 (Figure , left). HgCl2 forms a tetranuclear (Hg4Cl8) species through two μ3-chloro bridging modes between the cationic centers by two Cl– anions (Figure , right). This type of mercury polynuclear complex, although rare, has already been described in the literature.

elements.content: The crystal is a 3D pseudo-diamond-type coordination network, resulting from the interconnection of consecutive tectons 4 by pseudorectangular Hg4N4S4Cl8 complexes. The distance between Hg2+ cations within the tetranuclear unit of 4.225(4) Å is close to those reported for similar neutral Hg n Cl2n species. The organic tecton 4, in marked contrast with tectons 2 and 3, which behave as tetradentate units, acts as a hexadentate N4S2 neutral connector. The latter offers two monodentate pyridyl sites and two chelates of the NCCH2S type. Indeed, only two out of the four ArSCH2 S atoms participate in the coordination of Hg2+ with a Hg–S distance of ca 3.1 Å, whereas the other two are located at ca. 4.1 Å. The four N atoms of the pyridyl units occupy the apexes of a tetrahedron. The S atoms connecting the aromatic moieties are not involved in the binding of Hg2+. The interconnection between the two partners thus occurs through both N–HgII and S–HgII coordination bonds. Within the 3D network, two types of Hg2+ cations differing by both their geometry and surroundings are present. Those with a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry [Cl–Hg–Cl and N–Hg–Cl angles in the 90.24(5)–153.59(9)° and 89.20(11)–153.59(9)° ranges, respectively] are bound to one N and three Cl atoms [d Hg–N of 2.431(5) Å and d Hg–Cl of 2.3399(16), 2.3411(13), and 2.8430(12) Å]. The other ones with a distorted octahedral environment [N–Hg–Cl, Cl–Hg–Cl, S–Hg–Cl, and N–Hg–S angles of 94.69(11)–155.48(12)°, 84.14(11)–107.54(5)°, 80.29(5)–164.60(12)°, and 71.78(4)–96.29(5)°, respectively, and S–Hg–S of 61.85(7)°] are surrounded by one N, two S, and three Cl atoms with d Hg–N of 2.189(4) Å, d Hg–Cl of 2.3366(12), 2.6381(12), and 3.041(4) Å, and d Hg–S of 3.125(5) and 3.168(5) Å.

The CHCl3 molecules occupy the interstices in the crystal without any specific interaction with the framework.

In conclusion, we have demonstrated that compound 1 is a suitable backbone for the design of tectons 2–4, which are positional isomers differing by the position of the N atom on the pyridyl group. Their association with HgCl2 leads to the formation of mercury coordination networks with either HgCl2 or tetranuclear Hg4Cl8 moieties as bridging units interconnecting consecutive organic tectons. Interestingly, the dimensionality of the network (1D for 2, 2D for 3, and 3D for 4) may be controlled by the location of the N atom on the pyridyl unit. The formation of infinite networks and/or discrete polynuclear species based on the parent compound 1 and the pyridyl-appended tectons 2–4 is currently under investigation.
